keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, France's first ex-president to go to jail, is serving a five-year sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 campaign with money from Muammar Gaddafi.
Sarkozy was convicted of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, not of personally receiving Libyan funds.
The case involves secret meetings with Libyan intelligence officials in 2005 arranged via Ziad Tiakeddine, who died before the conviction.
Sarkozy has appealed the conviction, claiming his innocence and calling it a case of political revenge.
He is currently held in isolation at La Santé prison, with limited contact, exercise, and privacy.
His lawyer claims he will be released within weeks due to lack of justification for imprisonment.
President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin have expressed official support, emphasizing the human impact and the need for safety.
Sarkozy is allowed limited personal items, including books, and will pay a monthly fee for prison facilities.
The case is part of broader scrutiny of campaign finance ethics in French politics.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicolas Sarkozy, France’s first former president to go to jail, begins a five-year sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 presidential campaign with money from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi. While cleared of personally receiving the funds, he was convicted of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, who arranged secret meetings with Libyan intelligence officials in 2005 through intermediary Ziad Tiakeddine. Sarkozy is currently held in isolation at La Santé prison, where he faces restricted contact, limited exercise, and emotional distress. He has appealed the conviction, claiming he is an innocent man being punished for political revenge. French leaders, including President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin, have expressed public support, with Darmanin pledging to visit him. The case remains highly controversial, and France’s highest administrative court will deliver a verdict on the appeal in late November 2025.
title: Sarkozy enters jail over campaign financing - France's first ex-president behind bars
